headline: DOJ charges Julian Assange with conspiracy to help Chelsea Manning hack into the Pentagon to steal information
subHeadline: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange could soon be extradited to the United States after being arrested; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” Emily Compagno --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There it is.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.sentences: So this music of the day, so there's this theme with all of these songs. So the game is see if you can guess the theme. And I picked everyone's segments --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is west coast.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: I already know the theme, irritating music.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: If we get to your segment and then you're welcome. You're going to love it.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: You know this is car music. This is like, you know, you see those guys in the cars that go --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: With the hydraulics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's it. All right. I like it. All right, we'll see if you can do better than Juan. That's a very high bar from yesterday. Julian Assange could soon be extradited to the United States after being arrested this morning. He'd been hold-up in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London for almost 7 years before being evicted. Dramatic video showing the bearded WikiLeaks founder shouting as he was being hauled away.  The DOJ charging him with conspiracy to help former army intelligence analyst, Chelsea Manning, hack into the Pentagon's computers to steal information. Assange's attorneys are vowing to fight the extradition and saying it's a crackdown on the free press.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This sets a dangerous precedent for all media organizations and journalist in Europe and elsewhere around the world. This precedent means that any journalist can be extradited for prosecution in the United States for having published truthful information about the United States.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Edward Snowden, the former security contractor who leaked classified information about America surveillance program is calling Assange's arrest, quote, a dark moment for press freedom. Other reaction also pouring in.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If you believe in national security, if you believe in the safety of the United States, he's a villain.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In my opinion, Julian Assange is a hero. He'd be probably extradited here. We will see the indictment. And we'll probably have a show trial.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I do not regard him as a hero.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I just think it's about time. Julian Assange has put American lives at risk.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm glad that the wheels of justice are finally turning when it comes to Mr. Assange. I've never been a fan. I think what he did was a despicable and dangerous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And President Trump was also asked about it earlier.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I know nothing about WikiLeaks. It's not my thing. And I know there is something having to do with Julian Assange. I've been seeing what's happened with Assange. And that will be a determination, I would imagine, mostly by the attorney general.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, we'll get to that in a second. But people's opinions, Greg, of Julian Assange have really changed over the years. At first, the Democrats loved him, then they hated him, and where do they stand now?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, here's the deal. I emailed Dana and our producer Megan this morning. Was it about 9 AM? And I said I don't want to do this story because I can't even remember how I feel about Julian Assange, because we - - when The Five began, I guess this must -- well --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't tell you how I feel about Assange, and I don't think most of America even remembers because the last three to four years has been turned upside down. Every ideology, every side, every team sport has been somehow mixed up and changed, so I can't tell you how I feel. But I will find an argument in this. So people that are upset about this arrest are saying this is an attack on journalism, a dark day on journalism. If that is true, then you could never arrest anybody hacking into your computer or maybe even breaking into your apartment. Let's say my assistant goes into my computer and takes all of my emails, right? It doesn't matter if there's good stuff in there or bad stuff, she is stealing my property.   Let's say if she ships that over to the Washington Post and they have a story about me running this amazing drug ring out of my office, not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But the point is she has broken the law. Now if you want to commit journalism and there's a risk of breaking the law, then fine. You've got to pay the price. But if somebody is taking something that belongs to you, in this case that's what the charge is, is breaking into a state department computer and stealing.  If somebody comes in and is taking my emails, that is theft. Can you call theft journalism? I don't think you can. There is no reporting in theft, right? It's only a story if they find something in your emails. But that's not journalism. That is hacking. That's my theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is a great theory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Or maybe not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: One of many great theories from you, Greg. Dana, the Obama administration didn't charge Assange with what he is now being charged with, and people are saying, well, why was it not illegal then, but now it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I think it's because -- a couple of things, my opinion about Assange has never changed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You hate him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It is not about tribalism. Like, I'm team America. What he -- he's not even American. How does he get first amendment protection like for journalism?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: See, now we remember the shows we did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It was bad, right? I mean --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You were -- yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But I was right. Anyway. No -- OK, so that is very interesting, so one of the things about the Obama administration that they're stymied. One, there were actual intelligence harms that were done, diplomatic harms that resulted from this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Huge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then you had the whole thing about Bradley Manning's transformation. Now she's Chelsea Manning. There's all that -- Obama pardoned her at the end or commute her sentence.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then these people take on these mythical -- like they're heroes. Well, one a hero and one a heroin now, I guess. But the Obama administration couldn't figure out how to charge him without him being able to get journalistic protection.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But I think it's pretty amazing. And the Trump administration should be like, look at us, we figured it out, because they were the ones - - I don't know whether to additional investigation, maybe we'll find this out, but they were the ones who say this is not a first amendment claim, this is a national security threat. This was theft.  And for the rest of these people -- they want all of our information to be open and free to everybody, except for they howl about internet companies and privacy. It's bizarre.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It is bizarre. Speaking of bizarre, Juan, look great today after a big birthday night out, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah, that was me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It seems like the left, especially in the media, are trying to link President Trump with Julian Assange now, and they're pulling all these tapes, I guess, from the campaign when the president was saying WikiLeaks, I can't wait to read what they said. And I guess that's the new collusion, perhaps, is that it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think, you know, he was encouraging them. And then today, when he was here he says, WikiLeaks, I know nothing about WikiLeaks. I mean, it's so obviously wrong-headed and he's just trying to avoid any connection. But, you know, let's leave that alone. I mean, that's politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I'm very interested in this story because it's evidence that the -- first, the Ecuadorians threw him out and they say he was not a good (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he was also threatening their government.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Correct, that's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He'll release more information about Ecuador.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right. I didn't want to get on. But clearly, the first step is that they had been granting him asylum by holding him in that embassy. And once he's out, then he's subject to possible extradition. And that's when -- now, the U.S. charge is very careful. It doesn't get into the argument that Greg and Dana have been going through about journalism, not journalism. It simply says you were a co-conspirator in terms of helping Chelsea Manning to hack into our defense department computers. That's clearly illegal. That's their strongest stand. And that's why I think he can be then extradited, and he's likely to lose that case, in my opinion. When you ask me, though, I mean -- you know, I got hurt by WikiLeaks because I lost my cell phone and I was awakened in Las Vegas after it was hacked and they had my cell phone and I just -- it's just very unpleasant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I got to use that excuse once, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I got to say that I think there's a big --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You were answering the phone on air. Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I remember you answer -- people got a huge kick out of you answering my phone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Live on air?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. But afterwards -- no, in fact, Dana, afterwards people, you know, were still calling numbers, so I got rid of it and they'd say can I talk to Greg. What about me. What am I? Chopped liver here? But I got to say, serious news organizations, you -- well, you can be handy. You can walk in and say, hey, Juan, here's the Pentagon papers. And I'll say, well, let me see it. And I -- you know, but it's not me telling you here's how you go get -- here's how to break the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right, the allegation was he was trying to crack the passwords in order to infiltrate the state department system. And amazing how he was able to stay in the embassy for seven years. There must have been a lot of behind the scenes dealings between the Ecuadorians, and the British, and the U.S.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Well, no longer. And you guys -- all of you are -- your feelings, you inclination, they're totally correct. So legally think of it as a brilliant strategy, frankly, that the U.S., DOJ has undergone at this point because their burden of proof on this is so low, it's so clear, it's so simple. You are right, it has nothing to do with what was stolen or what was published or what was done. It's -- you broke into the house.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: So there's no defense beyond that, that even needs to be address at this point. The U.K.-U.S. extradition treaty is such that, right now, at this point, the next step after this whole jumpy and bail thing which we know he might face up to a year in jail in the U.K., is that they will, the U.K. court, will review the indicting, the charging document. And if there is the requisite specificity that goes to their level of acceptance, then they extradite him here. So, as we know, he also faces up to just simply five years in prison. And to me, that's also is interesting. We kind of talked about this before the show that the seven years of his self-imposed exile and the wretched creature we saw being brought out of the embassy today, he was in a worse hell and worse prison anticipating all of this and worrying about it and freaking out, than --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: By Pamela Anderson.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But, Emily, what about the statute of limitations, is there one?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: If there is, it's usually five years. However, because he was granted asylum by Ecuador, to me it tolls the statute of limitations. And there is no way that the U.S. underwent all of this in the grand jury proceedings last year without having them know that they can rely on that to toll it, which means to pause it. So I think the first amendment arguments --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: On the left people say that he's a hero because, you know, it turned out that he revealed some information about the U.S. government, in fact, monitoring or surveilling American citizens. And we, as Americans, have the right to know is the argument. But this is not about this. This is about a guy who was participating what I think was an illegal breach of American security.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, also a villain on the left for the Hillary Clinton and Podesta --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, yeah. Why did the New York Times and Washington Post use that illegal information?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. All right. Coming up, the New York Post eviscerates Congresswoman Omar over her outrageous 9/11 comments. But first, Democrats and the media in full-on meltdown mode after Attorney General Barr says the Trump campaign was spied on. The video is next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's in California, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The fallout -- well, wait. What is this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Northern California. Janis Joplin, Steve Miller, fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm very honored you chose this song for me and so is the Attorney General William Barr because he dropped this bombshell during a hearing on Capitol Hill yesterday.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I think spying on a political campaign is a big deal. Yes, I think spying did occur.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Democrats and some of the media are furious with Barr for saying spying did occur on the Trump campaign in 2016. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The chief law enforcement officer of our country is going off the rails. He is Attorney General of the United States of America, not the attorney general of Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The country's chief law enforcement officer went in front of Congress today and gave credence to a fact-less conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It feels like we -- that basically the attorney general gas-lit the country.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: When Barr opens his mouth, Trump's words come popping out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So he acted more like a personal lawyer for Donald Trump today, rather than the attorney general.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Is he a toodee? Is he saying the kind of language that Trump wants to hear him use?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. Greg, so I think of Bill Barr as somebody very professional, who chooses his words carefully, and tries to be very, you know, mature and reserved, but --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They brought back Brennan from the -- for that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And now they're using the words gas? You know what this is? The media trying to make a dozen sandwiches out of one cold cut. It's the collusion cold cut. They're down to one stale piece of ham. They need collusion helper, right? They need to make this meal bigger because now they're just arguing over words. Months ago it was about -- we have a Russian spy in the White House, now they're arguing over whether spy is positive or negative. You know, the media were expecting this giant, massive --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hoagie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Hoagie. And all they got was a wet noodle. But, I mean, the fact that they're bringing Brennan back is just like horrible. It's like, dude, he burned you already.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Now, Jesse, I do think that the attorney general -- obviously, he's very mature, this is not his first rodeo. He was confirmed unanimously by the senate when he worked for George H.W. Bush back in the day. But do you think that perhaps given the Democrats something to howl about was also part of his plan?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, he did say that there was spying, but he also said we know -- we need to know what it was predicated on, and that's where the investigation is now going to go. Greg's right. They're playing word games now. You know, it's not a crisis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't say radical Islam, don't say spying. Shawn Davis on twitter had a great line said, Obama's spy agents weren't spying, they were just using covert overseas intelligence assets and signal intelligence obtained via national security letters and FISA warrants to secretly collect and distribute information about private U.S. citizens. Permission to make an analogy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Say Juan gets framed for murder that he didn't commit, all right? Then he gets acquitted. Wouldn't you want internal affairs to look into how the whole thing happened?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I want to go home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly. I want to know how the whole thing happened. The media is so corrupt. They're not interested in the truth. They're not interested in the fact. You have a Democrat administration spying on a Republican presidential campaign, and the media is saying, nah, I don't care. I don't care. They don't care --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But they want to --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- they were complicit in it, that's why.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But they want to investigate Julian Assange and WikiLeaks and their involvement in spying on the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I just -- I have a very strong differing point of view here, because I think Bill Barr knew that he wasn't hanging out with his chums just talking. He knew he was in front of the Congress of the United States, and he use that term. And I think he did it in sort of a pandering gesture to President Trump's talk about coups and witch hunts.  I mean, to me, you know, the I.G., the inspector general at justice is apparently already looking into this. He should have simply said let's wait and see what the inspector general finds. And to Jesse's point, you know, a FISA report, even if you said we used a FISA document, that's thoroughly legal. That's part of the legal structure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But we don't know if it was done legally, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, of course -- it went to the court, it went to the FISA judges who said --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But we don't know if they use the dossier --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- to hoodwinked the FISA judge.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In other words, Jesse, it was repeatedly put before the FISA court judges who made a determination.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. So everything is on the up and up, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. So why can't we investigate it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The inspector general is. But he --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So is Barr.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. Barr says he has no evidence and then later tries to walk it back --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, no evidence. You have FISA warrants --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: FISA warrant is a legal document.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You have human intelligence assets --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, Juan, they had --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- in the 2016 campaign, there was Russian interference to help Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Blah, blah, blah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- and, of course, U.S. intelligence was doing its job to look into --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I get Emily in?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: One more thing. If you have a paid FBI informant trying to gain access to the Trump campaign, and he's being paid by the Obama administration --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. So, Juan, was Stefan Halper a paid informant, yes or no?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, by the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You have a paid British intelligence asset, Stefan Halper, trying to get a job on the Trump campaign and invited Papadopoulos over to London and set him up --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? This is a -- you're engaged in a torture conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're all coming out now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Emily, talk real fast and say what you want to say.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: OK. That none of these people have memories, but I do. In 2013 when there was an entire freak-out about the FISA court at that time, and about Verizon and Prism and how it was used, there was a bipartisan bill that was led by Rome Widen and Patrick Lahey to declassify significant rulings of the FISA court. And Nancy Pelosi, for example, back then said that the administration is just the custodian of info. And who owns it? The people, she said. And she was dang clear that she would not vote for the reauthorization of the Patriot Act in 05 and, again, in 2013. And here they all are not caring apparently this time around that there's a strong evidentiary assumption happening that in fact the government did expound its limits. And so, for some reason now, everyone cease to care. And I don't --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I like it when you use those big words and everyone goes --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, did you hear -- no, you missed it. She said dang.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I did hear that. I guess she's very restrain. All right, up next, the New York Post is not holding back with this powerful cover condemning Ilhan Omar's 9/11 comments.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Ilhan Omar under fire again, this time for these comments about the 9/11 terror attacks.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR, D-MINN.
utterances.sentences: Here's the truth. Far too long we have lived with the discomfort of being a second class citizen. And, frankly, I'm tired of it. And every single Muslim in this country should be tired of it.

utterances.speaker: OMAR
utterances.sentences: CAIR was founded after 9/11 because they recognized that some people did something and that all of us were starting to lose access to our civil liberties.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: The New York Post slamming the freshman congresswoman's 9/11 brushoff with this cover. The paper also ripping her in an op-ed, quote, how pathetic, a member of Congress can't acknowledge what happened on one of the most horrific days in U.S. history. Some people did something? Wow. What a way to describe the heinous surprise attack on America that claimed 3,000 lives. Omar was on the late show last night, but Steven Colbert did not ask her about the comments. She did, however, complain about what she says was a double standard over criticism of her anti-Semitic comments.

utterances.speaker: OMAR
utterances.sentences: This kind of double standard really is quite, you know, offensive and is very much embedded in a lot of our culture these days where you will have people get -- come after minorities for things that they say -- they might have insinuated.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: All right, Greg, that was a pretty powerful message from the New York Post.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it was one of their best covers. I -- first up, the media strategy here is to gauge our response or frame our response as more offensive than what she said. They're creating an armor of victimhood for her. But victimhood holds no candle to the families and the victims of 9/11 -- and a country that was devastated. But I'm going to say that she made -- she made a mistake. I don't think she excused terror. She thought that the truth would offend her hosts.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So she is guilty of Islamophobia because she believed that using the strong moral language about 9/11 would offend her friends at CAIR, so she conflated the aims of CAIR with the desires of the hijackers. Or else, why wouldn't she condemn it outright and say -- these could have been easily solved, as you've said, you know, these terrorists came and destroyed, and attacked this -- America, a country I loved dearly. But we have been harmed, too, since then. That would have been the shift. But she felt that she couldn't say that because she didn't want to offend her host. And that's in her own psychological conflation. She's the Islamophobe in that case, and she could have rectified it simply by just saying they were terrorists.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Totally, Dana she complains about a double standard.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well I think I talked in A block or the B block about Bill Barr as somebody who chooses his words carefully and sometimes you get in trouble for things because you say it on live TV and then he didn't really mean it that way. She chooses her words carefully as well and it's for that exact reason. Other than the Green New Deal and Medicare for All, the Republicans best political tool to use is to go against her and her comments. There are 31 Democrats that won this past year in 2018 where Trump won the district as well. So, Trump won in 2016, the Democrats squeaks out a win in 2018. They are the ones that are the targets for the Republicans to try to take back the House. And every single one of them is going to have to answer. Do you agree with Congresswoman Omar? And they're going to have to figure out a way to distance and this happens in wave elections like in 2018. People get swept ashore that wouldn't necessarily be able to usually win in an election and the Democrats have a real situation on their hands.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, what are your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean I can't believe she was on Colbert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's your take away.

And the Trump administration should be like, look at us, we figured it out, because they were the ones - - I don't know whether to additional investigation, maybe we'll find this out, but they were the ones who say this is not a first amendment claim, this is a national security threat. This was theft. And for the rest of these people -- they want all of our information to be open and free to everybody, except for they howl about internet companies and privacy. It's bizarre.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is bizarre. Speaking of bizarre, Juan, look great today after a big birthday night out, I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah, that was me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It seems like the left, especially in the media, are trying to link President Trump with Julian Assange now, and they're pulling all these tapes, I guess, from the campaign when the president was saying WikiLeaks, I can't wait to read what they said. And I guess that's the new collusion, perhaps, is that it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I think, you know, he was encouraging them. And then today, when he was here he says, WikiLeaks, I know nothing about WikiLeaks. I mean, it's so obviously wrong-headed and he's just trying to avoid any connection. But, you know, let's leave that alone. I mean, that's politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I'm very interested in this story because it's evidence that the -- first, the Ecuadorians threw him out and they say he was not a good (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he was also threatening their government.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct, that's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He'll release more information about Ecuador.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. I didn't want to get on. But clearly, the first step is that they had been granting him asylum by holding him in that embassy. And once he's out, then he's subject to possible extradition. And that's when -- now, the U.S. charge is very careful. It doesn't get into the argument that Greg and Dana have been going through about journalism, not journalism. It simply says you were a co-conspirator in terms of helping Chelsea Manning to hack into our defense department computers. That's clearly illegal. That's their strongest stand. And that's why I think he can be then extradited, and he's likely to lose that case, in my opinion. When you ask me, though, I mean -- you know, I got hurt by WikiLeaks because I lost my cell phone and I was awakened in Las Vegas after it was hacked and they had my cell phone and I just -- it's just very unpleasant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I got to use that excuse once, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I got to say that I think there's a big --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You were answering the phone on air. Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I remember you answer -- people got a huge kick out of you answering my phone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Live on air?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. But afterwards -- no, in fact, Dana, afterwards people, you know, were still calling numbers, so I got rid of it and they'd say can I talk to Greg. What about me. What am I? Chopped liver here? But I got to say, serious news organizations, you -- well, you can be handy. You can walk in and say, hey, Juan, here's the Pentagon papers. And I'll say, well, let me see it. And I -- you know, but it's not me telling you here's how you go get -- here's how to break the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, the allegation was he was trying to crack the passwords in order to infiltrate the state department system. And amazing how he was able to stay in the embassy for seven years. There must have been a lot of behind the scenes dealings between the Ecuadorians, and the British, and the U.S.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, no longer. And you guys -- all of you are -- your feelings, you inclination, they're totally correct. So legally think of it as a brilliant strategy, frankly, that the U.S., DOJ has undergone at this point because their burden of proof on this is so low, it's so clear, it's so simple. You are right, it has nothing to do with what was stolen or what was published or what was done. It's -- you broke into the house.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So there's no defense beyond that, that even needs to be address at this point. The U.K.-U.S. extradition treaty is such that, right now, at this point, the next step after this whole jumpy and bail thing which we know he might face up to a year in jail in the U.K., is that they will, the U.K. court, will review the indicting, the charging document. And if there is the requisite specificity that goes to their level of acceptance, then they extradite him here. So, as we know, he also faces up to just simply five years in prison. And to me, that's also is interesting. We kind of talked about this before the show that the seven years of his self-imposed exile and the wretched creature we saw being brought out of the embassy today, he was in a worse hell and worse prison anticipating all of this and worrying about it and freaking out, than --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By Pamela Anderson.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But, Emily, what about the statute of limitations, is there one?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: If there is, it's usually five years. However, because he was granted asylum by Ecuador, to me it tolls the statute of limitations. And there is no way that the U.S. underwent all of this in the grand jury proceedings last year without having them know that they can rely on that to toll it, which means to pause it. So I think the first amendment arguments --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: On the left people say that he's a hero because, you know, it turned out that he revealed some information about the U.S. government, in fact, monitoring or surveilling American citizens. And we, as Americans, have the right to know is the argument. But this is not about this. This is about a guy who was participating what I think was an illegal breach of American security.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, also a villain on the left for the Hillary Clinton and Podesta --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, yeah. Why did the New York Times and Washington Post use that illegal information?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. All right. Coming up, the New York Post eviscerates Congresswoman Omar over her outrageous 9/11 comments. But first, Democrats and the media in full-on meltdown mode after Attorney General Barr says the Trump campaign was spied on. The video is next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's in California, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The fallout -- well, wait. What is this --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Northern California. Janis Joplin, Steve Miller, fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm very honored you chose this song for me and so is the Attorney General William Barr because he dropped this bombshell during a hearing on Capitol Hill yesterday.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: I think spying on a political campaign is a big deal. Yes, I think spying did occur.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Democrats and some of the media are furious with Barr for saying spying did occur on the Trump campaign in 2016. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The chief law enforcement officer of our country is going off the rails. He is Attorney General of the United States of America, not the attorney general of Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The country's chief law enforcement officer went in front of Congress today and gave credence to a fact-less conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It feels like we -- that basically the attorney general gas-lit the country.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: When Barr opens his mouth, Trump's words come popping out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: So he acted more like a personal lawyer for Donald Trump today, rather than the attorney general.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Is he a toodee? Is he saying the kind of language that Trump wants to hear him use?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. Greg, so I think of Bill Barr as somebody very professional, who chooses his words carefully, and tries to be very, you know, mature and reserved, but --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They brought back Brennan from the -- for that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And now they're using the words gas? You know what this is? The media trying to make a dozen sandwiches out of one cold cut. It's the collusion cold cut. They're down to one stale piece of ham. They need collusion helper, right? They need to make this meal bigger because now they're just arguing over words. Months ago it was about -- we have a Russian spy in the White House, now they're arguing over whether spy is positive or negative. You know, the media were expecting this giant, massive --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hoagie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hoagie. And all they got was a wet noodle. But, I mean, the fact that they're bringing Brennan back is just like horrible. It's like, dude, he burned you already.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Now, Jesse, I do think that the attorney general -- obviously, he's very mature, this is not his first rodeo. He was confirmed unanimously by the senate when he worked for George H.W. Bush back in the day. But do you think that perhaps given the Democrats something to howl about was also part of his plan?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he did say that there was spying, but he also said we know -- we need to know what it was predicated on, and that's where the investigation is now going to go. Greg's right. They're playing word games now. You know, it's not a crisis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't say radical Islam, don't say spying. Shawn Davis on twitter had a great line said, Obama's spy agents weren't spying, they were just using covert overseas intelligence assets and signal intelligence obtained via national security letters and FISA warrants to secretly collect and distribute information about private U.S. citizens. Permission to make an analogy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Say Juan gets framed for murder that he didn't commit, all right? Then he gets acquitted. Wouldn't you want internal affairs to look into how the whole thing happened?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I want to go home.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly. I want to know how the whole thing happened. The media is so corrupt. They're not interested in the truth. They're not interested in the fact. You have a Democrat administration spying on a Republican presidential campaign, and the media is saying, nah, I don't care. I don't care. They don't care --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they want to --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- they were complicit in it, that's why.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they want to investigate Julian Assange and WikiLeaks and their involvement in spying on the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just -- I have a very strong differing point of view here, because I think Bill Barr knew that he wasn't hanging out with his chums just talking. He knew he was in front of the Congress of the United States, and he use that term. And I think he did it in sort of a pandering gesture to President Trump's talk about coups and witch hunts. I mean, to me, you know, the I.G., the inspector general at justice is apparently already looking into this. He should have simply said let's wait and see what the inspector general finds. And to Jesse's point, you know, a FISA report, even if you said we used a FISA document, that's thoroughly legal. That's part of the legal structure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But we don't know if it was done legally, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, of course -- it went to the court, it went to the FISA judges who said --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But we don't know if they use the dossier --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- to hoodwinked the FISA judge.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In other words, Jesse, it was repeatedly put before the FISA court judges who made a determination.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So everything is on the up and up, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So why can't we investigate it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The inspector general is. But he --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So is Barr.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. Barr says he has no evidence and then later tries to walk it back --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, no evidence. You have FISA warrants --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: FISA warrant is a legal document.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You have human intelligence assets --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, Juan, they had --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- in the 2016 campaign, there was Russian interference to help Donald Trump --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Blah, blah, blah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and, of course, U.S. intelligence was doing its job to look into --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I get Emily in?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One more thing. If you have a paid FBI informant trying to gain access to the Trump campaign, and he's being paid by the Obama administration --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Juan, was Stefan Halper a paid informant, yes or no?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, by the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You have a paid British intelligence asset, Stefan Halper, trying to get a job on the Trump campaign and invited Papadopoulos over to London and set him up --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? This is a -- you're engaged in a torture conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're all coming out now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Emily, talk real fast and say what you want to say.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: OK. That none of these people have memories, but I do. In 2013 when there was an entire freak-out about the FISA court at that time, and about Verizon and Prism and how it was used, there was a bipartisan bill that was led by Rome Widen and Patrick Lahey to declassify significant rulings of the FISA court. And Nancy Pelosi, for example, back then said that the administration is just the custodian of info. And who owns it? The people, she said. And she was dang clear that she would not vote for the reauthorization of the Patriot Act in 05 and, again, in 2013. And here they all are not caring apparently this time around that there's a strong evidentiary assumption happening that in fact the government did expound its limits. And so, for some reason now, everyone cease to care. And I don't --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like it when you use those big words and everyone goes --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, did you hear -- no, you missed it. She said dang.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I did hear that. I guess she's very restrain. All right, up next, the New York Post is not holding back with this powerful cover condemning Ilhan Omar's 9/11 comments.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Ilhan Omar under fire again, this time for these comments about the 9/11 terror attacks.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR, D-MINN.
utterances.utterance: Here's the truth. Far too long we have lived with the discomfort of being a second class citizen. And, frankly, I'm tired of it. And every single Muslim in this country should be tired of it.

utterances.speaker: OMAR
utterances.utterance: CAIR was founded after 9/11 because they recognized that some people did something and that all of us were starting to lose access to our civil liberties.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: The New York Post slamming the freshman congresswoman's 9/11 brushoff with this cover. The paper also ripping her in an op-ed, quote, how pathetic, a member of Congress can't acknowledge what happened on one of the most horrific days in U.S. history. Some people did something? Wow. What a way to describe the heinous surprise attack on America that claimed 3,000 lives. Omar was on the late show last night, but Steven Colbert did not ask her about the comments. She did, however, complain about what she says was a double standard over criticism of her anti-Semitic comments.

utterances.speaker: OMAR
utterances.utterance: This kind of double standard really is quite, you know, offensive and is very much embedded in a lot of our culture these days where you will have people get -- come after minorities for things that they say -- they might have insinuated.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg, that was a pretty powerful message from the New York Post.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it was one of their best covers. I -- first up, the media strategy here is to gauge our response or frame our response as more offensive than what she said. They're creating an armor of victimhood for her. But victimhood holds no candle to the families and the victims of 9/11 -- and a country that was devastated. But I'm going to say that she made -- she made a mistake. I don't think she excused terror. She thought that the truth would offend her hosts.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So she is guilty of Islamophobia because she believed that using the strong moral language about 9/11 would offend her friends at CAIR, so she conflated the aims of CAIR with the desires of the hijackers. Or else, why wouldn't she condemn it outright and say -- these could have been easily solved, as you've said, you know, these terrorists came and destroyed, and attacked this -- America, a country I loved dearly. But we have been harmed, too, since then. That would have been the shift. But she felt that she couldn't say that because she didn't want to offend her host. And that's in her own psychological conflation. She's the Islamophobe in that case, and she could have rectified it simply by just saying they were terrorists.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Totally, Dana she complains about a double standard.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well I think I talked in A block or the B block about Bill Barr as somebody who chooses his words carefully and sometimes you get in trouble for things because you say it on live TV and then he didn't really mean it that way. She chooses her words carefully as well and it's for that exact reason. Other than the Green New Deal and Medicare for All, the Republicans best political tool to use is to go against her and her comments. There are 31 Democrats that won this past year in 2018 where Trump won the district as well. So, Trump won in 2016, the Democrats squeaks out a win in 2018. They are the ones that are the targets for the Republicans to try to take back the House. And every single one of them is going to have to answer. Do you agree with Congresswoman Omar? And they're going to have to figure out a way to distance and this happens in wave elections like in 2018. People get swept ashore that wouldn't necessarily be able to usually win in an election and the Democrats have a real situation on their hands.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, what are your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean I can't believe she was on Colbert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's your take away.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Think about this. Imagine you're in from out of town and you get tickets to The Late Show and they try to go more out and you're like, oh! My God who is this person. She's not an A lister, B lister. She comes out and watch this, it's funny, they probably won't show it. She doesn't know how to wave. She goes like this with her hand. She goes like this like a robot, which is weird. She sits down, acts totally uncomfortable and insecure. The audience is dead silent. It's probably the worst booking of all time but on to what she said, she doesn't know how to read the room. She's in Congress now, she's not back in her district in Minnesota with her radical friends. She represents the United States of America. And as a member of Congress you do not act dismissively towards 9/11 and about the 9/11 hijackers. She obviously doesn't get that and that's a huge problem. And what she does is, this is her MO, she says dumb and controversial things. She gets called out for it and then she plays the victim and plays the race card. And it's not a clever act and it's getting tired and you know who is probably the most tired of it, Nancy Pelosi. Nancy Pelosi, they do well. The Democrats when they try to keep a lid on the radicalism. Omar has come in the first three months blown the whole lid off. I mean it's April and she's already been accused of anti-Semitism and anti-Americanism and we're not even like three months into the new Congress.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Totally. So, Juan I mean what does the House leadership do? What do they do with us?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think they have to do much. I mean I don't - I think Dana is way off track on this. I don't think that they can go after her, they go after AOC. They make them into demons. Look that's not the issue that's going to be at stake in 2020 in the presidential race or midterms. President Trump is also playing this. Jewish people come vote. You know what, everybody sees that for what it is. And the New York Post that's an inflammatory cover. There are lots of news organizations that wouldn't even use that cover and haven't used it. But I think that you know even if you say it's appropriate because of her comments I would say it doesn't live up. It's not enough what she said to justify something as upsetting to me personally as to see a moment when I think thousands of people died in that moment. And my fellow Americans. I just think it wasn't enough for that. I will say this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you think is it a good reminder though. It was not the point?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Never forget.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I think it was an attempt again because she's an easy target and--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just legitimate rage in that cover.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but that cover doesn't fit with what she said. She was flipped and I think she didn't speak carefully, Greg, But I do think she needs to be careful because people will pick apart what she says. She has a legitimate point; she's misstated the date when CAIR was founded. But she has a legitimate point in terms of whether or not they were fellow Americans who are Muslim were on unfairly demonized in the aftermath of it.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right, we've got to go. Up next, Amazon employees are reportedly listening to what you tell Alexa.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love it. All right. Amazon's Alexa isn't the only one listening to your conversation it turns out the tech giants' employees are listening too. Amazon reportedly has thousands of workers reviewing, transcribing, recordings from its echo device. The company says it's being done so that Alexa can better understand and respond to human speech. But the new information is raising serious privacy concerns. That's because employees are reportedly saying they have chatrooms where they share amusing recordings among themselves. Amazon is saying it takes customers security and privacy very seriously. Dana, you're making noises.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I am.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've heard them before.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe three years ago I got an Alexa and then we used it a little bit. I was kind of confusing. As for the Jeopardy question of the day. The joke of the day. Like maybe that could you play a podcast. Never I couldn't get it to work that well. Technological owner operated problems and then we went away on that trip to Africa. We came back and it didn't work, and I couldn't get it to reset. And they're like well you can't connect. We can't connect to your Wi-Fi and basically--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It died of loneliness.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It died, and I've never plugged it back in because of this concern. I don't - remember that story we had where the conversation accidentally gets uploaded to all the friends.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Contact list. I don't want anything to do with.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, the stuff I talk about with Peter is disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You've heard it. I thought you'd heard it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jasper.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Emily they haven't done anything elite. There's nobody saying that what they're doing is illegal. I think the point here is that so many of us Americans. Maybe Dana is in this. We don't know what we're doing when we buy these devices. I mean because there are unintended consequences to Facebook, to Amazon and Google. They're using us.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Totally, I think this is one more example of a Pandora's box of data and information about which we know nothing. And we have no control. And I think the things that stuck out to me about this are number on the whole - the human designation of critical data. So, for example if your conversations include banking data then these guys are like we're marking that one. It reminded me of those mass discovery teams that are employed for big cases in law where just a bunch of young attorneys are like looking through documents. This one's privileged. Is this one and it's so rife with error. And then I just want to bring up two questions that it's - they're open ended. What is the duty and what is the scope? Do these people I keep saying kids do these people have a duty to report when they overhear a sexual assault. Because from what we know thus far when they brought it to the chain they didn't. And then in terms of scope. Remember when law enforcement tried to subpoena evidence from Alexa of certain crimes. Then Amazon was like no way. And so, to me I think it also - it just raises a lot of questions certainly more than answering that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Jesse, if it raises a lot of questions would you put your faith in the company?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. This is what I do since I know Alexa is spying on me. I like to butter up my eavesdroppers. So, when I have the Alexa on, I'll say something like I think Jeff Bezos is an incredibly innovative capitalist or since we know the Chinese are listening, I'll be at Mar-a-Lago because we know they have spies there and I'll save over cocktails, I'll just drop this in a conversation. Chairman Xi is a strong leader. And we know the CIA is watching and listening. So, I'll text my mom. I think the CIA is just trying to keep us safe, because Juan, the CIA, Alexa, Chinese all spying on us. Can I use that word spying? Is that OK? Can we say spying?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Mr. Attorney General.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do I need to say surveillance.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I guess Donald Trump; they do that one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
